metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The application of Le Chatelier's principle to identify factors that favour the yield of a chemical reaction

le_chatelier_definition.name: Le Chatelier's Principle Definition
le_chatelier_definition.formula: System opposes change to restore equilibrium
le_chatelier_definition.correct: Le Chatelier's principle states that if an equilibrium system is subjected to a change, the system will adjust itself to partially oppose that change and restore equilibrium.

completely eliminate.error: The opposition is PARTIAL, not complete.
completely eliminate.fix: The system partially counteracts the change. It cannot fully eliminate it.
completely eliminate.action: If you add reactant, some (not all) is converted to product. The new equilibrium has more reactant than before.

amplify.error: The system opposes the change, not amplifies it.
amplify.fix: Opposition means working against the disturbance, not enhancing it.
amplify.action: Think of it like a thermostat: when temperature rises, it cools; when it drops, it heats.

ignore.error: Equilibrium systems DO respond to changes.
ignore.fix: The system shifts to counteract stress. This is the core of Le Chatelier's principle.
ignore.action: Add reactant → forward reaction speeds up. The system responds.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what 'oppose' means in equilibrium.
persistent.action: Write out 5 examples where you identify: the change, the opposition, and the new position.

adding_reactant_effect.name: Effect of Adding Reactant
adding_reactant_effect.formula: Add reactant → forward reaction favoured → equilibrium shifts right
adding_reactant_effect.correct: Adding a reactant increases its concentration. The system opposes this by favouring the forward reaction, shifting equilibrium toward products.

reverse reaction.error: Adding reactant favours FORWARD, not reverse reaction.
reverse reaction.fix: The system reduces excess reactant by consuming it in the forward reaction.
reverse reaction.action: If you add N₂ to N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, the system makes more NH₃ to use up some N₂.

no effect.error: Adding a species definitely affects equilibrium.
no effect.fix: Any change in concentration of a reactant or product causes a shift.
no effect.action: Add reactant = more collisions between reactants = forward reaction speeds up.

shifts left.error: 'Left' means toward reactants. Adding reactant shifts RIGHT toward products.
shifts left.fix: Adding reactant → use it up → forward reaction → more products = shift right.
shifts left.action: Draw an arrow: reactant added on left → equilibrium moves right to consume it.

persistent.gap: You're confusing direction of equilibrium shifts.
persistent.action: Memorise: ADD reactant → CONSUME it → FORWARD reaction favoured → shifts RIGHT.

adding_product_effect.name: Effect of Adding Product
adding_product_effect.formula: Add product → reverse reaction favoured → equilibrium shifts left
adding_product_effect.correct: Adding a product increases its concentration. The system opposes this by favouring the reverse reaction, shifting equilibrium toward reactants.

forward reaction.error: Adding product favours REVERSE, not forward reaction.
forward reaction.fix: The system reduces excess product by converting some back to reactants.
forward reaction.action: If you add NH₃ to N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, some NH₃ breaks down to N₂ and H₂.

no effect.error: Adding product definitely shifts the equilibrium.
no effect.fix: Increased product concentration means Q > K, so reverse reaction is favoured.
no effect.action: Calculate Q after adding product. It exceeds K, so system shifts left.

shifts right.error: 'Right' means toward products. Adding product shifts LEFT toward reactants.
shifts right.fix: Adding product → decompose it → reverse reaction → more reactants = shift left.
shifts right.action: Think: the system 'rejects' the extra product by breaking some of it down.

persistent.gap: You're confusing which direction equilibrium shifts when products are added.
persistent.action: Memorise: ADD product → REMOVE it → REVERSE reaction favoured → shifts LEFT.

removing_species_effect.name: Effect of Removing Species
removing_species_effect.formula: Remove species → reaction favoured that replaces it
removing_species_effect.correct: Removing a reactant or product causes the system to shift in the direction that replaces the removed species.

reaction away from removed species.error: The system replaces what was removed, not moves away from it.
reaction away from removed species.fix: Remove product → forward reaction makes more product. Remove reactant → reverse makes more reactant.
reaction away from removed species.action: The system 'fills the gap' left by the removed species.

no shift.error: Removing a species definitely causes a shift.
no shift.fix: Lowering concentration of any species disturbs equilibrium.
no shift.action: Industrial processes often remove product as it forms to drive reaction forward.

opposite direction.error: The shift is toward the removed species, not away.
opposite direction.fix: Remove product → forward reaction replaces it. Remove reactant → reverse replaces it.
opposite direction.action: Think 'replacement': what reaction recreates the missing species?

persistent.gap: You don't understand that removal creates a 'gap' the system fills.
persistent.action: For each removal scenario, ask: which reaction makes more of what was removed?

temperature_exothermic.name: Temperature Effect on Exothermic Reactions
temperature_exothermic.formula: Exothermic: increase T → reverse favoured; decrease T → forward favoured
temperature_exothermic.correct: For exothermic reactions (ΔH negative), increasing temperature favours the reverse (endothermic) direction. Decreasing temperature favours the forward (exothermic) direction and increases yield.

increasing temperature increases yield.error: For exothermic reactions, DECREASING temperature increases yield.
increasing temperature increases yield.fix: High temperature favours the endothermic direction. For exothermic forward reactions, that's reverse.
increasing temperature increases yield.action: Write heat as a product for exothermic: A + B ⇌ C + heat. Adding heat (↑T) shifts left.

temperature has no effect on yield.error: Temperature always affects equilibrium position for reactions with ΔH ≠ 0.
temperature has no effect on yield.fix: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes the value of K.
temperature has no effect on yield.action: Unlike concentration or pressure, temperature changes K itself.

forward reaction favoured at high temper.error: For exothermic reactions, HIGH temperature favours REVERSE.
forward reaction favoured at high temper.fix: High T → system releases heat → endothermic direction → reverse for exothermic reactions.
forward reaction favoured at high temper.action: Ammonia synthesis is exothermic. High T gives lower yield (but faster rate).

persistent.gap: You're not linking temperature to the direction of heat flow.
persistent.action: Always write 'heat' as a pseudo-reactant or product, then apply Le Chatelier's.

temperature_endothermic.name: Temperature Effect on Endothermic Reactions
temperature_endothermic.formula: Endothermic: increase T → forward favoured; decrease T → reverse favoured
temperature_endothermic.correct: For endothermic reactions (ΔH positive), increasing temperature favours the forward direction and increases yield. Decreasing temperature favours the reverse direction.

decreasing temperature increases yield.error: For endothermic reactions, INCREASING temperature increases yield.
decreasing temperature increases yield.fix: Endothermic reactions absorb heat. Adding heat (↑T) drives them forward.
decreasing temperature increases yield.action: Write: heat + A + B ⇌ C. Adding heat shifts right.

reverse favoured at high temperature.error: For endothermic, HIGH temperature favours FORWARD.
reverse favoured at high temperature.fix: Endothermic = heat is a reactant. More heat → more forward reaction.
reverse favoured at high temperature.action: Decomposition of limestone (CaCO₃ → Caite + CO₂) is endothermic. High T helps.

K is unchanged.fix: K increases for endothermic reactions when temperature increases.
K is unchanged.action: For endothermic: ↑T → ↑K → more products at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly predicting temperature effects on endothermic reactions.
persistent.action: Draw energy profiles for endo and exo. Higher T always favours uphill direction.

temperature_changes_K.name: Temperature Changes K
temperature_changes_K.formula: Only temperature changes the equilibrium constant
temperature_changes_K.correct: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes the value of the equilibrium constant K. Concentration, pressure, and catalysts do NOT change K.

concentration changes K.error: Concentration changes equilibrium POSITION, not K.
concentration changes K.fix: K is constant at constant temperature. Concentration shifts position until K is restored.
concentration changes K.action: Add reactant → Q < K → forward reaction until Q = K again. K unchanged.

pressure changes K.fix: Pressure shift restores the original K value at a new equilibrium position.
pressure changes K.action: Compress gas mixture → shift → same K, different concentrations.

catalysts change K.error: Catalysts speed up BOTH directions equally. K unchanged.
catalysts change K.fix: Catalyst lowers activation energy for forward AND reverse. Equilibrium reached faster, same position.
catalysts change K.action: With or without catalyst, same final concentrations, just different time to reach them.

persistent.gap: You think K changes with factors other than temperature.
persistent.action: Make a table: Factor | Changes Position? | Changes K? Temperature is the only 'Yes, Yes'.

pressure_moles_of_gas.name: Pressure and Moles of Gas
pressure_moles_of_gas.formula: Increase P → favours side with fewer moles of gas
pressure_moles_of_gas.correct: Increasing pressure (or decreasing volume) shifts equilibrium toward the side with fewer moles of gas. The system reduces pressure by producing fewer gas particles.

side with more moles of gas.error: Increasing pressure favours FEWER moles, not more.
side with more moles of gas.fix: To oppose increased pressure, the system reduces the number of gas particles.
side with more moles of gas.action: N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃: 4 moles → 2 moles. High P favours products (fewer moles).

no effect on equilibrium.error: Pressure affects equilibrium if there are unequal moles of gas on each side.
no effect on equilibrium.fix: Only if moles are equal on both sides is there no pressure effect.
no effect on equilibrium.action: H₂ + I₂ ⇌ 2HI: 2 moles → 2 moles. No pressure effect. But N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃ IS affected.

changes K.fix: K remains constant. The system shifts to restore K at new concentrations.
changes K.action: Same K, different equilibrium concentrations after pressure change.

persistent.gap: You're not counting gas moles correctly to predict pressure effects.
persistent.action: For every equation, count gas moles on each side. More moles = higher pressure contribution.

inert_gas_effect.name: Effect of Adding Inert Gas
inert_gas_effect.formula: Inert gas at constant V → no effect on equilibrium
inert_gas_effect.correct: Adding an inert gas at constant volume increases total pressure but does NOT change partial pressures of reactants or products, so equilibrium position is unchanged.

shifts toward fewer moles.error: Partial pressures are unchanged, so no shift occurs.
shifts toward fewer moles.fix: Only partial pressures of reacting species matter, not total pressure.
shifts toward fewer moles.action: Add argon to N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃ at constant V. [N₂], [H₂], [NH₃] unchanged. No shift.

shifts toward more moles.error: No shift occurs because partial pressures are unchanged.
shifts toward more moles.fix: Inert gas doesn't participate in the reaction. It doesn't affect reacting species.
shifts toward more moles.action: Inert gas is like a bystander—present but not involved in the equilibrium.

changes K.error: K is unchanged by inert gas addition.
changes K.fix: K only changes with temperature. Inert gas has no effect on K or position.
changes K.action: Before and after adding inert gas: same concentrations, same K, same position.

persistent.gap: You think total pressure matters, but only PARTIAL pressures of reacting species matter.
persistent.action: Calculate partial pressures before and after adding inert gas. They're identical.

catalyst_equilibrium.name: Catalyst Effect on Equilibrium
catalyst_equilibrium.formula: Catalyst speeds both directions equally, no change to position or K
catalyst_equilibrium.correct: A catalyst increases the rate of both forward and reverse reactions equally by lowering activation energy for both. It does NOT change equilibrium position or K, only the time to reach equilibrium.

increases yield.error: Catalyst does NOT increase yield. Same equilibrium, reached faster.
increases yield.fix: Catalyst lowers Ea for both directions. Same final position, less waiting time.
increases yield.action: With catalyst: same [products] at equilibrium, just get there sooner.

favours forward reaction.fix: Ea decreases for forward AND reverse. Neither direction is preferred.
favours forward reaction.action: Draw energy profile: catalyst lowers the peak for both forward and reverse paths.

changes K.error: K is unchanged by a catalyst.
changes K.fix: K only changes with temperature. Catalyst affects kinetics, not thermodynamics.
changes K.action: Catalyst = faster equilibrium. Temperature = different equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You think catalysts affect equilibrium position.
persistent.action: Memorise: catalysts affect RATE (how fast), not POSITION (where equilibrium lies).

optimising_yield.name: Optimising Yield
optimising_yield.formula: Use Le Chatelier's to maximise products at equilibrium
optimising_yield.correct: To maximise product yield: add excess reactant, remove product as it forms, and adjust T and P to favour the product side based on ΔH and moles of gas.

only temperature matters.error: Multiple factors affect yield: concentration, temperature, and pressure.
only temperature matters.fix: All Le Chatelier factors can be adjusted to favour products.
only temperature matters.action: Haber process: high P, moderate T, remove NH₃. Multiple optimisations used together.

high temperature always best.error: High T only helps yield for ENDOTHERMIC reactions.
high temperature always best.fix: For exothermic, low T favours products. But rate is slower at low T = compromise needed.
high temperature always best.action: Ammonia: exothermic, so low T gives better yield but slower rate. Use ~450°C as compromise.

adding catalyst increases yield.error: Catalyst speeds reaction but doesn't change final yield.
adding catalyst increases yield.fix: Catalyst helps reach equilibrium faster but same final concentrations.
adding catalyst increases yield.action: With Fe catalyst, ammonia forms faster but same % yield at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You're not systematically applying all Le Chatelier factors to optimise yield.
persistent.action: For any reaction, list: ΔH, moles of gas each side, then state optimal T, P, and concentration adjustments.

le_chatelier_definition.title: Le Chatelier's Principle
le_chatelier_definition.content: Le Chatelier's principle is a fundamental concept in chemistry that predicts how equilibrium systems respond to stress. When any change is made to a system at equilibrium, the system shifts to partially counteract that change and establish a new equilibrium position. The key word is 'partially' - the system moderates but cannot eliminate the disturbance.
keyPoints: The system OPPOSES changes, working against the disturbance
Opposition is PARTIAL - a new equilibrium is reached, not the original
Applies to changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure

adding_reactant_effect.title: Effect of Adding Reactant
adding_reactant_effect.content: When a reactant is added to an equilibrium system, its concentration increases above the equilibrium value. The system responds by consuming some of the excess reactant through the forward reaction, producing more products. The equilibrium shifts to the right (toward products).
keyPoints: Add reactant → Q < K → forward reaction favoured
Equilibrium shifts RIGHT toward products
New equilibrium has more products than before, but not all added reactant is used

adding_product_effect.title: Effect of Adding Product
adding_product_effect.content: When a product is added to an equilibrium system, its concentration increases above the equilibrium value. The system responds by decomposing some of the excess product through the reverse reaction, producing more reactants. The equilibrium shifts to the left (toward reactants).
keyPoints: Add product → Q > K → reverse reaction favoured
Equilibrium shifts LEFT toward reactants
New equilibrium has more reactants than before

removing_species_effect.title: Effect of Removing Species
removing_species_effect.content: Removing a species from equilibrium creates a 'gap' that the system works to fill. If product is removed, the forward reaction is favoured to replace it. If reactant is removed, the reverse reaction is favoured. Industrial processes often remove products continuously to drive reactions toward completion.
keyPoints: Remove product → forward reaction replaces it → shift right
Remove reactant → reverse reaction replaces it → shift left
Continuous removal can drive reaction almost to completion

temperature_exothermic.title: Temperature Effect on Exothermic Reactions
temperature_exothermic.content: For exothermic reactions (ΔH < 0), heat can be considered as a product. Increasing temperature adds 'heat', so the system shifts left (reverse) to consume excess heat. Decreasing temperature removes 'heat', so the system shifts right (forward) to produce more heat and more products.
keyPoints: Exothermic: write as A + B ⇌ C + heat
Increase T → reverse favoured → K decreases → lower yield
Decrease T → forward favoured → K increases → higher yield (but slower rate)

temperature_endothermic.title: Temperature Effect on Endothermic Reactions
temperature_endothermic.content: For endothermic reactions (ΔH > 0), heat can be considered as a reactant. Increasing temperature adds 'heat', so the system shifts right (forward) to consume excess heat and produce more products. Decreasing temperature removes 'heat', so the system shifts left (reverse).
keyPoints: Endothermic: write as heat + A + B ⇌ C
Increase T → forward favoured → K increases → higher yield
Decrease T → reverse favoured → K decreases → lower yield

temperature_changes_K.title: Temperature Changes K
temperature_changes_K.content: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes the equilibrium constant K. Changes in concentration, pressure, and addition of catalysts shift the equilibrium position but do NOT change K. When temperature changes, a completely new K value applies.
keyPoints: Only temperature changes K
Concentration and pressure change position, but K stays constant
Catalysts speed reaction but don't change K or final position

pressure_moles_of_gas.title: Pressure and Moles of Gas
pressure_moles_of_gas.content: For gaseous equilibria, increasing pressure causes the system to shift toward the side with fewer moles of gas (to reduce pressure). Decreasing pressure causes a shift toward more moles of gas. This only applies when there are unequal moles on each side.
keyPoints: Increase P → shift toward FEWER gas moles
Decrease P → shift toward MORE gas moles
Equal moles on both sides → NO pressure effect
pressure_moles_of_gas.formula: Count coefficients of gaseous species on each side

inert_gas_effect.title: Effect of Adding Inert Gas
inert_gas_effect.content: Adding an inert gas at constant volume increases total pressure but does NOT change the partial pressures of the reacting gases. Since concentrations are unchanged, there is no effect on equilibrium position. Only partial pressures of reacting species matter.
keyPoints: Inert gas at constant V → no effect on equilibrium
Partial pressures of reactants and products unchanged
Total pressure increases, but this doesn't affect equilibrium

catalyst_equilibrium.title: Catalyst Effect on Equilibrium
catalyst_equilibrium.content: Catalysts lower the activation energy for both forward and reverse reactions equally. This speeds up the approach to equilibrium but does not change the equilibrium position or K value. The same final concentrations are reached, just faster.
keyPoints: Catalysts speed BOTH directions equally
No change to equilibrium position or K
Same yield, reached faster

optimising_yield.title: Optimising Yield
optimising_yield.content: To maximise product yield, apply Le Chatelier's principle systematically: add excess reactant, remove product as it forms, adjust temperature based on ΔH, and adjust pressure based on gas moles. Industrial processes often compromise between optimal yield (thermodynamics) and acceptable rate (kinetics).
keyPoints: Exothermic: low T for yield, but this slows rate → compromise needed
Fewer product moles: high P increases yield
Remove product continuously to drive reaction forward
Use catalyst to achieve acceptable rate at moderate conditions
